introduction.title: Overview
introduction.p: One of the most important mathematical ideas in calculus is that of an accumulation of change for physical quantities. We start by thinking about change and accumulation of change for sequences. Eventually, this will lead us to the calculus ideas of the derivative and of definite integrals.

In this section, we learn explore sequences through their differences and accumulations. The differences for a sequence defines a new sequence which we call the increments. We introduce the mathematical notation for adding the terms of a sequence using summation notation. We also learn about conditions which determine when a sequence will be increasing, decreasing, concave up and concave down based on properties of the increments.

subsection.title: Sequence Differences and Accumulation
subsection.p: When we first discussed arithmetic sequences, we learned that they had a constant increment. For example, the sequence x=(1, 4, 7, 10, 13, \ldots) has a constant increment of +3. Sometimes, more complicated sequences can also be understood which have variable increments.

example.p: Consider x = (5, 7, 11, 17, 25, \ldots). The increments are not always the same, but we can find a pattern.

The increments form a new sequence, which is the sequence of even numbers. The next value in the sequence , if the pattern continues, will be x_5=x_4+10=35. Our recurrence relation will require a formula involving the index variable. Consider the pattern:
x_0 &= 5 x_1 & = x_0 + 2 = x_0 + 2(1) x_2 & = x_1 + 4 = x_1 + 2(2) x_3 & = x_2 + 6 = x_2 + 2(3) x_4 & = x_3 + 8 = x_3 + 2(4)
The pattern can be written as a backward recurrence x_{n} = x_{n-1} + 2n or as a forward recurrence x_{n+1} = x_n + 2(n+1).

subsection.p: The previous example illustrated how we can use the increments of a sequence to describe that sequence. We introduce some notation to calculate these increments.

statement.p:
Given a sequence x=(x_n)_{n=n_0}^{\infty} with first index n_0, we define the increment sequence or backward difference named 
abla x=(
abla x_n)_{n=n_0+1}^{\infty} defined by 
abla x_n = x_n - x_{n-1}. We can also define the forward difference \Delta x=(\Delta x_n)_{n=n_0}^{\infty} defined by \Delta x_n = x_{n+1} - x_{n}.

subsection.p: We will only use the backward difference when discussing increments because it is more natural when we work with summation notation. Analogous ideas and formulas could be stated for the forward difference but will not be needed.

For any sequence, we can compute its increments using backward differences. In a reverse manner, if we are told the increments and an initial value, we can reproduce the original sequence using a backward recurrence, x_n = x_{n-1} + \nabla x_n. We call the resulting sequence the accumulation of the increments.

statement.p: Given a sequence of increments, x=(x_n)_{n=n_0}^{\infty}, we can define the accumulation sequence u using the backward recurrence, u_n = u_{n-1} + x_n, \quad n \ge n_0, and an initial value.

subsection.p: Notice that the first index of the increments will always be one later than the first index of the corresponding accumulation.

statement.p: Find the first six terms of the accumulation sequence named s with increments defined by x=(x_n)_{n=-1}^{\infty} = (-3,0,3,6,9,\ldots) and whose first value is 12.

solution.p: Because accumulation uses a backward recurrence, the first index of s will be n=-2. We can compute the values of the accumulation s by successively adding the increments.

subsection.p: Because we can recreate a sequence using its increments and initial value, knowing that information is enough to identify a sequence. In particular, if we have two different ways of describing a sequence and they both have the same initial value and same increments, then they are the same sequence.
We can use this theorem to show that an accumulation sequence has an explicit formula by showing that the backward differences of that formula describe the increment sequence.

statement.p: Show that the sequence of odd integers have explicit formula x_n=2n-1, n=1, 2, 3, \ldots.

solution.p:
We need to verify the initial value and the increments. The first odd integer is 1, which agrees with x_1=2(1)-1 = 1. So our explicit formula has the correct initial value. Next, we verify the increments. Odd integers have increments \nabla x_n = 2, which we verify using the formula.
x_n - x_{n-1} & = \big(2n-1\big) - \big(2(n-1)-1\big) &= 2n-1-(2n-3) = 2n-1-2n+3 &= 2
Since x_n has the correct initial value and correct increments, x_n=2n-1 is the explicit formula for the sequence of odd integers, n \ge 1.

statement.p: Using the sequence of odd integers x_n=2n-1, n \ge 1, as the increments for an accumulation sequence s with s_0=0, show that s_n = n^2. That is, show that the accumulation of the odd integers is the sequence of squared integers.

solution.p:
We start by seeing if the statement makes sense by checking the first few values.
x_1 &= 1 x_1 + x_2 &= 1+3 = 4 x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= 1+3+5 = 9
The pattern appears to hold for the first few values.

The initial value using the explicit formula is s_0 = 0^2 = 0, the same initial value as stated for the accumulation. In order to prove that it will always be true, we need to compare the actual increments. The increment of s is computed as the backward difference,
\nabla s_n &= s_{n} - s_{n-1} &= n^2 - (n-1)^2 &= n^2 - (n^2-2n+1) &= 2n-1.
Because \nabla s_n = x_n, we know that s_n is the accumulation of the odd integers with initial value s_0 = 0.

subsection.title: Sequence Behavior
subsection.p: Recall that one of the reasons to study sequences was that they could motivate how we think about functions generally. The behavior of a sequence, both in terms of monotonicity and concavity, can be understood in terms of its increments or differences.

First, we look at monotonicity. When an increment sequence has positive values, the corresponding accumulation sequence will be increasing. When an increment sequence has negative values, the accumulation sequence will be decreasing. We can extend this idea to an entire range of index values. A sequence is monotone over an index range if it steadily increases or decreases over the entire range.

statement.p: Let u be a sequence and let m and n be valid indexes (integers) with m \lt n.

subsection.p: The monotonicity of an accumulation sequence is completely determined by the sign of the increment sequence. Suppose u is an accumulation of the sequence x. Because \nabla u_k = u_k - u_{k-1} = x_k, we know that u_k = u_{k-1} + x_k. If x_k \gt 0, then u_k \gt u_{k-1}; if x_k \lt 0, then u_k \lt u_{k-1}. This is generalized to an entire range of index values in the following theorem by using the transitive property of inequalities.

statement.p: Suppose a sequence u is an accumulation sequence for a particular increment sequence x and m and n are integers with m \lt n
The sequence u is increasing on the index range m,\ldots,n if and only if the sequence \nabla u_k = x_k \gt 0 for every k=m+1,\ldots,n.
The sequence u is decreasing on the index range m,\ldots,n if and only if the sequence \nabla u_k = x_k \lt 0 for every k=m+1,\ldots,n.
Consider the sequence x defined explicitly x_k = 2k-13, \quad k=1, 2, 3, \ldots, and the accumulation sequence u defined with x as increments and initial value u_0=10.
Determine index ranges on which u is increasing and on which u is decreasing. Compute enough values of u to demonstrate these results and create a graph.

solution.p: By , the accumulation sequence u will be increasing on the range 6,\ldots,\infty and will be decreasing on the range 0,\ldots,6. Notice that the minimum value of the accumulation sequence as at index value n=6 where the transition from decreasing to increasing occurs. We go back one because increments are the backward difference.

We will compute sequence values for n \le 12. First, we compute the values of the increments x using the explicit formula. Once we have the increments, we start with the initial value u_0=10 and then repeatedly add one increment at a time to find additional values of u. For conciseness in the table, we will use the common index variable n for both x and u. The value x_0, although potentially defined by the explicit formula, is not used and so is not shown. With the sequence computed, a plot of the sequence is shown.

subsection.p: We now turn our attention to the concavity of the sequence. In the previous example, although the accumulation sequence u was first decreasing and then increasing, the increment sequence x was increasing over all index values. Indeed, for x_k = 2k-13, we have \nabla x_k = 2 \gt 0. The increments started at a negative value and increased steadily, originally become less and less negative and eventually becoming positive. This had the effect of making the graph of the accumulation sequence bend upwards. In this case, the data actually correspond to an upward-opening parabola.

The definition of concavity for functions was that the slope increased over an interval. However, for sequences, the increments are the same as the slopes. Consequently, concavity of a sequence is based on whether the increments are increasing or decreasing.

statement.p: Suppose u is a sequence with increments \nabla u_k = x_k and m and n are index values with m \lt n.
We say that u is concave up over the range m,\ldots,n if the increment sequence x is increasing over the range m,\ldots,n.
We say that u is concave down over the range m,\ldots,n if the increment sequence x is decreasing over the range m,\ldots,n. then

subsection.p: Because we can test if the increment sequence is increasing or decreasing by looking at its increments, the concavity of a sequence is determined from the increments of its increments, which is called the second backward difference.

statement.p:
Suppose u is a sequence with increments 
abla u_k = x_k. The second backward difference of u, written 
abla^2u_k, measures the backward difference of the increments, 
abla^2 u_k = 
abla x_k = x_k - x_{k-1}. The first index of 
abla^2 u_k is two greater than the first index of u. (A second forward difference \delta^2 u is defined similarly but will not be used.)

theorem.title: Second Difference Test for Sequence Concavity

statement.p:
Suppose u is a sequence with increments 
abla u_k = x_k. If 
abla^2 u_k \gt 0 for all k with m \lt k \lt n, then x is increasing and u is concave up on the index range m-1,\ldots,n. If 
abla^2 u_k \lt 0 for all k with m \lt k \lt n, then x is decreasing and u is concave down on the index range m-1,\ldots,n. If 
abla^2 u_k = 0 for all k with m \lt k \lt n, then x is constant and u is linear on the index range m-1,\ldots,n.
Determine the monotonicity and concavity of the accumulation sequence u with increments x_k = k^2 -90k + 1600, k=1,2,3,\ldots.

solution.p:
We need to check values in the intervals.
x_0 &= 0^2-90(0)+1600 = 1600 x_{30} &= (30)^2-90(30)+1600 = -200 x_{70} &= (70)^2-90(70)+1600 = 200
This shows that x_k \gt 0 for k=1,\ldots,24, that x_k \lt 0 for k=25,\ldots,65, and that x_k \gt 0 for k=66,\ldots. Consequently, the accumulation sequence is increasing for the range k=0,\ldots,24, decreasing for the range k=24,\ldots,65, and again increasing for the range k=65,\ldots.

For concavity, we need to determine where the increment sequence is increasing or decreasing. We compute the backward differences of x_k or second backward differences of u.

abla^2 u_k = 
abla x_k &=x_k - x_{k-1} &= ig(k^2-90k+1600 ig) -  ig((k-1)^2-90(k-1)+1600 ig) &=k^2-90k+1600 -  ig(k^2-2k+1-90k+90+1600 ig) &=k^2-90k+1600 - k^2 + 92k+1-1691 ig) &=2k-91
This equals zero if k=45.5. We have 
abla^2 u_k \lt 0 for k=2,\ldots,45 and 
abla^2 u_k \gt 0 for 46,\ldots. Thus, x_k is decreasing and the accumulation u_k is concave down on the range k=1,\ldots,45, and x_k is increasing and the accumulation u_k is concave up on the range k=45,\ldots.

A plot of the sequence with initial value u_0=0 is shown below. Points within the range where the plot is concave down are colored in blue. Points within the range where the plot is concave up are colored in orange. The index k=45 is included in both ranges and is considered the inflection point.

li.p: Every sequence x can be interpreted as an accumulation of increments, which we measure using backward differences, \nabla x_n = x_n - x_{n-1}.

Given a sequence x = (x_n)_{n=1}^{\infty}, we can define a new sequence u called the accumulation sequence of x with a recurrence relation u_{n} = u_{n-1} + x_n and an initial value u_0 so that the increments of u is given by the sequence x, \nabla u_n = x_n.
If two sequences share the same initial value and the same increments, then the sequences are identical. (See .)
The shows that a sequence is increasing over the range of index values for which the increments are positive and decreasing over the range of index values for which the increments are negative.

The shows that a sequence is concave up over the range of index values for which the second backward differences are positive and concave down over the range of index values for which the second backward differences are negative.
